author: bobby k
content:
About a week ago I was in here moping about how I had like one thing on the calendar for the entire month and it was freaking me out. you guys had really great feedback, and @Josh Bowman compared it to walking on an invisible path in Mario which is so spot on. It ended up being a major positive because I was able to say yes to several things that came up since (which included two of the coolest opportunities I’ve had all year, one with producing for a new fav artist of mine and the other with a band I listened to a ton as a kid). All in all, hitting those scary moments where you’re broke and unbooked can be a rock solid motivator, and somehow yet again the universe is looking out for me. Didn’t even need to finish my soundbetter profile 😂

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Long Post alert, but touches on a few things we harp on around here. 

So my little bro is in town- we made dinner for one of his oldest friends who just moved to town with his wife. He’s a fantastic mandolin player and his wife is a singer/songwriter. 

Of course I did the ol’ studio walk through, listening to all the tunes on the ear calibration playlist, then let them play some of their own favs. Of course they’re blown away and have never heard music like this etc. 

But to drive the point home I show them a song @Rollmottle and I turned around in just over 24 hours. “The reason for the speakers & treatment etc is so we can make decisions quickly blah blah blah.”  I pull up the session and we listen through and they’re loving it- but I’m noticing it doesn’t have the 3D thing that all the other music we’ve been listening to has. 

Then I show them the mastered version. An mp3. It’s louder and better sounding and all, until the first BGV stack hits… then it’s IMMERSIVE. We listened to the whole thing again just to enjoy the magic and notice all the ways the master improved it. So far beyond zapping resonances and making it loud, @Rollmottle made it sound… important. Made *me* sound like a good mixer. 

It was heavier lifting for him cause I didn’t have the benefit of time for fresh ears or to detail the vocal the way I normally would. Also had the good fortune of having @Ross Fortune on speed dial and on GMT to give it a listen at 5am PST. 

I’d you’re curious, or dubious, I’ll DM files so you can hear what I’m talking about. 

TL;DR: monitoring matters, fresh perspective matters. Don’t produce mix *and* master your own shit.

author: BatMeckley
content:
God I love this discord. 
To me 90% of the reason big producers are paying many thousands a day to be in a studio the past 15-20 years is to just not have to worry about shit. Anyone can make a record at home these days; part of being in an “actual” studio is the cocoon of creativity. If the assistant takes more than a couple of minutes to patch anything in, bring up the piano, or recommend the best Thai place in town, they’re blowing it. I had an assistant once at this place famous for making cookies on site, bring me my normal plate of cookies I always ask for and while I was comping I ate half of one, put it back on the plate, and continued working. He didn’t say a word, got up, grabbed the plate, and disappeared for a few minutes and came back. “Hey man, I know you normally house the entire plate of cookies so when you put that one back I checked with the kitchen and last week I guess they changed the cookie recipe, and they’re gonna make em like they used to for you.” 😂😂. I asked for that dude every session after, less for the cookies but more for the insane attention to detail and telepathy. One of max’s engineers started as a Conway assistant, and as good of an engineer as he was he also prepped the best Hookahs and was just a great hang. Max ended up hiring him for his own studio. We’re in a people business, try to be attentive and a good person to have around, for all the reasons that go beyond knowing how to set an attack on an 1176. 

The flip side is, if you’re booking a studio as a producer, the assistants are what really make the studio run. Treat them well. Know their names. Give them credit. No assistant on any session I ever did paid for their own meal, they got what the artist got.  They most of the time got engineer credits. Help them along. As with all things, mutual respect goes a long way.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Because I'm a huge Penn Jillette fan, I'll quote it from one of his books (which he has paraphrased many other times in essays and on podcasts):

"The big secret of magic is we are willing to work harder to accomplish something stupid than you can imagine. We'll practice things for years that you wouldn't consider investing an hour in. You can imagine spending half of your life under a bridge learning to play sax like Sonny Rollins, but you can't imagine spending five minutes learning to drop a palmed cell phone into a little pocket behind a cardboard cut out of Chris Angel while hanging across around its neck and talking a mile a minute without the slightest pause. I had to practice that a lot. A lot more than you can imagine. I had to practice it a lot more than you think it's worth. Our big secret is that it's worth more to us to do our tricks then you can even imagine. Our deep secret is simply misplaced priorities."

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Tl;dr- where you are matters as much as who you are. 

I’m also from a small town, moved to LA trying to get famous and got my ass handed to me by artists who were better looking & more talented and yet were still struggling to be seen. But I kept at it because I’m tenacious, (read: delusional, as all artists must be.)

I was able to work *for* some of those artists cause I had a diverse skillset, and I was full time music after about 4 years, by the time I was 26. Doing gigs at hotels and playing guitar or recording for other people, teaching guitar, leading music at churches, all the while pouring evening last ounce of money & energy into my artist career, until my last real artist project broke up the week we were supposed to sign our first record deal. I was 36. 

That’s when I moved to Nashville and really gave myself over to music directing and producing and writing for other artists. I did it as a consolation while I regrouped to find my next thing, but for some reason, when I made the move all the sudden my whole career made sense to me. 

As it turns out, my real joy comes not from the sound of my own voice, but from helping others find theirs. When I acquiesced to that very real, very culturally counterintuitive calling, I thrived. 

All the sudden I was playing music with and for a bunch of my heroes, and all my friends who were artists starting getting famous. And (shocker) I was really glad I wasn’t one of them. 

I always thought that my calling was to help people feel less alone in the world, and that the music I made was the vehicle for that calling. In the end, it turns out it was the relationships i built through music that were the real vehicle.  

It took me a long time to figure out who I was, and the cities I was in played a huge role in that story. Nashville built its whole industry on people who want to *help* artists, not just *be* artists. 

I miss LA every day but I’m in the right place. So, my friend, where is the right place for you?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I met Nile a few years ago when my boss had a writing session with him at Abbey Road studio 1. I set up a rig to continue editing vocals for a Hot Chip album in one booth, while they worked away self contained in the main control room. 

Nile had been a huge influence on my old band, and Hot Chip had been part of the soundtrack to my college years. Weird working on one on headphones while watching the other grooving away on The Hitmaker through the glass. 

It was a real “this is pretty cool” moment.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Growing up in Ireland, without PP I wouldn’t have known that making records could be a legitimate career.

It showcased real life *professionals* working at a high level, and was my introduction to the discourse around the industry. Having only experienced studio work as a cottage industry up to that point, PP opened my eyes to avenues I could pursue that I wouldn’t have known even existed otherwise (recording engineer is different to mixing engineer is different to producer is different to songwriter??!). It all seems very rudimentary now, but I was starting from literally nothing in a place with few (if any?) visible role models.

I learned so much from it on a technical level - from basic stuff like what a Pultec is and how people use it (connecting the dots between my cracked Waves bundle - Puigtec and who tf JJP was), what “a vocal chain” might look like and the purpose of each stage…

True, the interviews did become unbearable, but there was a golden era between eps around 30-90 at a time when outside of working in the studio world, there weren’t many other sources of good information from people who were really doing it.

Huge appreciation for Dave, and I hope he and his family get the support they need.

author: Josh
content:
Two years ago I said “no more rock/metal projects” 

Two weeks ago I worked on my first label gig. It was rock/metal. 

Because I’m so far removed from the genre and don’t care for most of the sonics, lyrics, or really anything about the music (generally speaking), I found my ideas stuck out in ways they never did when I was working in the genre. The band valued my input on the deeper production stuff, the lyrics, my melodies and cadences. 

It was my mission to not hate these songs, that was my ONLY goal (pessimistic, but realistic), and I ended up loving every single one of them.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Ok I'm gonna go in depth about this because I think it's FASCINATING.

The top three songs have an overlapping core fanbase that is largely unrepresented (or maligned) in popular culture: the white working class.

But none of them are really straightforward "country." 

The first song is a viral hit that seemingly comes from an authentic Appalachian kid talking about class. Despite his very explicit statements about hating political division, it has of course been wildly politicized because everything on the internet is these days.

The second song is a white male country singer covering a black lesbian female's iconic song ALSO about class. Talk about intersectionality...

The third song is the longest running solo male #1 song on the Hot 100 from the biggest star in country music (and really one of the biggest stars in the world... just, again, not covered by the current fashion of mainstream culture). It's a kinda-country-but-kinda-just-pop song co-written by the biggest country writer in history (Ashley Gorley) as well as once-rapper-and-Dr-luke-protege J Kash.

The rest of the chart is interesting too. #4 is a four year old taylor swift song that has gained traction online from her current tour so the label started pushing it as a single. 

There are two Olivia Rodrigo songs, signaling a true new superstar.

There are two songs from the Barbie soundtrack. In a "dying" movie industry currently on strike, when is the last time two songs from a movie soundtrack have been in the top 10? I dunno.

And lastly, there's only 1 trap song. The majority of these songs are people playing real instruments and writing more "classic" singer-songwriter songs. Rap music is really having a lull after a decade of dominance.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
@Nomograph Mastering said a thing in #deleted-channel (go read it, it’s for everyone really) that resonated with another lesson I learned annoyingly late.

Ruarí: “For years I would open conversations by telling people how much I loved LA, and that I was here to learn. Shock horror a bunch of people opened up and taught me a bunch of shit”


My version in a sentence: “**Open mouths get fed.**”

If you want to learn something from someone, or you want a job, or whatever, or you’re engineering writing sessions when you really want to be writing - people will not guess these things. Get used to asking (respectfully, etc) and being clear about what you want, and more often than not (IME) people will be happy to help you, or send you in the right direction.

It won’t apply to everyone, but I wish I’d realised it way earlier.

author: Matt Huber
content:
VCA’s rule! I use them all the time.

You get a note back “can we have all chorus harmonies ride up on these 3 phrases”

Create a quick VCA (Soundflow script ftw), and easily ride them together without having to worry about fussing with preexisting automation on each track.

author: LAPhill
content:
I don't know why I didn't think of this sooner, but the closest parallel to the seismic shift of AI might be samples, even more so than things like digital recording or Pro Tools. When Hans Zimmer recorded an orchestra and started writing music with a DAW and showing clients mockups, nothing was ever the same. For a long time (even now!) the pencil-and-paper people griped about how it wasn't real composition. Orchestras feared that they would all be replaced by computers. But ultimately, everyone had to come to terms with the new world order and adapt. There was a period in the mid-90s through mid-late 2000s where orchestral writing was reduced to nothing more than long notes and short notes. All of the nuance was gone, because the tech couldn't handle it yet and people blamed the tech. Many mourned the loss of true orchestral writing, yearning for a by-gone era. 

But eventually, people learned to harness these new tools and they met the technology on its own terms. People are doing wildly innovative things with samples now, we've moved completely past the era of "can I make a convincing clarinet come out of my keyboard?" Orchestras and live musicians have not been replaced. Sure, the process is different than it used to be, but that's how innovations work. All of us would be living very different lives without samples of drums, guitars, orchestras, synths, etc. There will be a generation coming up where AI is already a thing, they won't have ever lived in the before-times. Just like those here who've never cut to tape. It's okay.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Got a call this week to save a track. Producer turned it in pretty half baked and didnt give the mixer any direction. The first time the artist heard it was first pass at mix, and he HATED it. 

Artist was SUPER uncomfortable about the whole thing, but didn’t trust the producer to get it done for a bunch of reasons. 

1) the producer rushed the vocal recording. Artists wanted more takes but basically got bullied out of the room. 
2) The artist wanted to be there for the comp at least, producer refused. As I said, first time he heard it was after first mix pass. 
3) producer baked some Sonics into the vocal that were very outside for the artist, and there were bad edits & poor Melodyne work to boot. 


Now not only is the mixer gonna have to mix the vocals all over again (we’re retracking,) but all the other shit I’m adding/changing. 

So this producer made the artist uncomfortable and then made more work for everyone, on a major label budget. 

I’m not gonna speculate on the why, but there are some lessons here.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Awesome. I'm seeing this right now with a friend's band, so ima jump on the bandwagon here. I just took over mixing the album, which has been in progress for years. Everybody tells me the producer/band leader is this prolific asshole, constantly blowing up at people and impossible to please. The previous mixer had been mixing this thing for months/over a year and everyone was worn out/not getting results. I was really reluctant to take on the project for fear of being intimidated/failing to deliver.

I've made a point of greeting the producer at every step with clear communication, enthusiasm, and an open mind. I genuinely love the music and have made a point of letting him know how much fun it's been to work on the stuff. And, similar to your story, we were basically approved on the first track within 4 mixes and the guy seemed really really happy.

Everyone just said this guy was a hopeless asshole, but what I saw was a guy who was working so hard to bring a vision to life and just struggling to get there; self-financing, overseeing everything, etc... and it's fairly complex, hip hop and soul vibes with practically a full orchestra and 3 vocalists, so it's a lot to manage. Not trying to excuse the asshole behavior, but I see the frustration and I really wanted to highlight how much cool work he had done and that, without any fuss or needless back and forth, we would just get it where it needed to go. i tried to just think about how exciting it could be to finally hear these songs that've been bouncing around in his head actually come out of the speaker the way he imagined. We've got 7 songs almost done now and I've grown so much just from these attitude alignments i've picked up from spending time here.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I happily worked from home for two solid years, very focused and disciplined. I was doing maybe 2-7 days a month engineering in commercial studios as well, so that kept my *being in the room with people and making shit happen in the moment* side satisfied.

In terms of getting work done, home was great, I had more time to use exercising and cooking. Moving to a mix room away from home turned out to have a much greater positive effect on my mental health than I thought though, and now I don’t know if I could go back. It’s really helped me separate work from life (even though I still routinely wake up thinking about work), and I much prefer co-writing there as it’s a real sanctuary.

Finance-wise, it’s certainly taking a chunk. The dream longer term is to have an amazing, amazing shed in a back garden, within commutable distance to London/major music hub… just like everyone else in their 30s here.

author: BatMeckley
content:
The worst thing you can do to someone, especially in this business, is bullshit them on their art. It’s hard enough to make it work in the best case scenarios, telling someone that clearly doesn’t have it that they do, seems really cruel to me. “Hey buddy, I don’t have the courage to confront you so I’m knowingly gonna let you walk into a lifetime of disappointment and hurt” seems like a far shittier move than an honest opinion. 

Having said that, Zach’s guy has a real chance. He’s clearly at the stage of trying to figure out the bridge between making what matters to him matter to the listener. But at least IMHO he’s closer to it than he is far. Recognizing the actual bottlenecks verses the excuses we tell ourselves (“man, she won’t date me because I’m not rich/talk enough” no, she won’t date you cause you’re an ass and you slept with her friend) helps us move forward in a meaningful way.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Another quick story, I was streaming a production/mix with my old boss / mentor / producer Jon Kaplan, thinking I was close and just wanting an outside ear. 

During the first chorus, Kaplan goes “solo the kit… flip the phase on the mono room and dip 400hz in that mic.”

He didn’t even ask if there *was* a mono room mic. 

And I kid you not, all the sudden the snare jumped like 4db in the mix. I muted the claps I was using to bolster 2 & 4 and the mix was done. 

That was one of the most virtuousic moments of listening I’ve ever witnesssed.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
not a weird question at all. something that took me a long time be comfortable with. i now say "i'm a record producer and songwriter." if people have follow ups or have decent knowledge, ill get into more specifics and clarify.

it's always a little awkward when someone follows up with things like "what genre?" or "anything i would know?" but you just figure out how to slowly let out more information if people are interested. 

"i produce music" is usually a pretty good response, even if you're more of a mixer or engineer or whatever.

i always try and remember that most everyone is interested because making music has a cool cache, but they always feel like an idiot for not knowing how it works. they often feel more uncomfortable than you do. treat your response as a thing to make them feel good.

author: BatMeckley

I can almost guarantee this is tuning the low strings a few cents flat to compensate for a heavy picking hand. My first “real” band in Australia the guitarist showed me this on the low E string and it blew my mind how much better the rhythm guitars sat in the track after. 

Now I ABSOLUTELY melodyne a bass track. Purists be damned. So many “mix” problems are really tuning problems.

author: Adam Thein
content: Re: overbooking/crunch times - I can’t afford a full time assistant or even a part time but I recently started hiring another engineer to help me out of these jams - and it’s great to be able to share your workflows and have someone learn what you need in order to help you when the sauce is getting thick.  Had a client reach out with a tight 2 day deadline right ahead of a move and I passed politely and recommended another engineer who said yes then bailed on the project 24 hours later It was my word so I jumped in and hired my other friend to split the fee with me and we got a royal amount of editing done in 24 hours and I got my client hooked up and happy.  Sometimes you gotta compromise your plans big time to make it happen.  If you can afford to build in spare days at your rate best to do that and then if you are ahead of schedule sneak in lighter quick turn work.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Not sure how long you feel like you've been in this state, but it kinda sounds like you're describing the place just before it's your lyrics and arrangements on NMF. 

It's hard to draw parallels because I came up pre streaming and there's just a lot more people making records. But I had my first 3-4 things that started getting attention get taken away from me by managers/ labels/ bigger producers/ bigger mixers. Once I got to that next level it was obvious why I wasn't the guy yet. But if you're working on things that are at some point getting out there in a real way, that's the place that most people are before they jump up. 

Some of it is opportunity, some of it is skillset, some of it is time management (if you're hustling, it helps to turn great shit around before everyone else), and some of it is just the intangibles that come from more reps. 

My One Direction song came out 17 years after I first recorded the first band I was in. I'm not recommending anyone spend 17 years doing something all the time for no real money. But that's how it went for me.

author: Slow Hand
content:
On reflection, the material benefits of *Option #1* are a nice selling point, but I think the bigger opportunity is to harness the superpower of rendering hit music at will. It would give me tremendous sway over the music industry once everyone comes to recognize that I can't miss. I would leverage that influence to make some positive changes where I can. Set up some institutions to cultivate and nurture the next generation of artists. 

Presumably, while the hit music I’m making runs counter to my personal tastes, it seems reasonable that it would still be valuable to *someone*. Just not to me. That will be my curse. I would dutifully churn out hits as fast as I am able to and gift humanity with a tsunami of unimpeachable pop awesomeness that will endure for a century. My sacrifice would be everyone else’s gain.

Counter-intuitively, by saturating the market with my personal brand of songwriting it would inspire the next generation of songwriters. Unable to compete with my torrent of sure-shot pop badness they would respond by writing new music that is the direct antithesis of my own brand of hits. With a little luck, the musical output of these writers would be exactly what I wished to hear all along.

That’s a win/win right there. I just have to suffer a bit. I choose *Option #1*.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’m not familiar with your work, so this is not a direct attack at all, but my experience has been that the real problem with most tuners is they don’t actually know what a good vocal is supposed to sound like. I’ve taught many people everything I know about melodyne and they come out with a WILDLY different result than I do.

Having said that, pro tip 1: get your key commands for note choice, separate, stretch, formant, and vibrato mapped out to the buttons on your trackball, or in my case now, a row of buttons under your left hand on your keyboard. Makes a HUGE difference in not just your speed,  but also how intuitively you tune once switching tools becomes easy and reflexive.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I love that question. Honestly I’m really good at guitar and I have the same feeling… 
Understanding your weaknesses can be a real strength as a producer. Sometimes that means finding a partner who can clothe those weaknesses, sometimes it can drive you to get really good at new things. 
I was in a band where the worst player also wrote the best melodies. It took him a while but his shit was hooky as hell. His ear was his gift, not his virtuosity. Even though I was the better player, I relied on him for that. I’m not telling you to give up on the pursuit, just offering a little perspective and encouragement.

author: popaganda.
content: One little tag on last nights convo: to hope is to believe that there are things happening outside of one’s control that could bring about beautiful results. That the universe will not crumble into chaos if I let go of the reins. When I play music with people I want to be skating around in Hopeland. I want us to believe anything could happen, and it might shock us. Things beyond what we think we’re capable of. Not “I’ve learned all this and you’ve learned all that so let’s do this and that with what we know.” But reaching into spaces where we’re accessing ideas we didn’t know we knew. Every act of earnest hope (not naive wishful thinking) increases the chances that when you sit down to make something it will be fresh, inspiring, and surprising.

author: cian riordan
content: Sonic consistency amongst songs on a record is one of those things that gets harder as you move further through the production processes. In an ideal world, you'd map out an aesthetic for a record in pre-production and make choices in recording & production to try and stay within those lines, whatever that means. A real world example I have is when I was doing the last Mini Mansions album, we locked onto a few H3000 patches that sort of defined how the drums and ambience would sound throughout the record. We obviously didn't use it on everything, but it helped thread the needle through a wildly diverse batch of songs. After that, having one person mix the whole album will undoubtedly help tie together a record that's been all over the map in production -- be it different styles or producers. As someone that often is tasked with doing this, I am always referencing other songs in the album to try and make sure things are sounding 'consistent'. By the time mastering comes, everything should sound 99% complete.

author: Rollmottle
content: this is certainly a take! i think i could make the same overrated argument about every part of the modern record making process other than the performance and songwriting. the job being "simple" doesn't make it any less vital to the process. after all, mixing is pretty simple too. 😉 i don't think  color-correction makes or breaks a film, but if done thoughtfully, it can certainly elevate what's already there, especially if the writing, performances and production are all dialed in. a lot of misconception around mastering comes because the other parts of the process AREN'T dialed in and expect mastering to do something it's not supposed to do.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When you feature an artist who writes an original verse (like a rap verse on a pop song), you will generally give them a low double digit piece of the publishing plus a flat fee for their "appearance" on the song. And there may also be a master side royalty for the artist, but that depends on a lot of factors and is negotiable either way.

Two examples:
We had Rich The Kid feature on a song I did. The original had 3 writers. Rich did his verse and ad libs and sent the files. Since he was signed to the same publisher, he did it for $5k and 15% of pub.

When Kendrick featured on Sia "The Greatest", I don't know what he took on pub (likely would be more than 15% but not too much) but his fee was $250k.

author: spectrummasters
content: Hi, yes so......within the genres I’m most involved in currently hip/hop , drill and rnb the samples we choose and the patterns we create for these samples are all “trendy “ in a sense that it’s important in our genres to be seeking to present new sounds and patterns that others catch onto . This would be being the new wave . It’s vital in uk street music to be a creator of the wave / up on the new wave .....to garner attention . This dates back to jungle....where the producer/engineers were pioneering completely new sounds and rhythms via sampler technology midi and sampled breakbeats (amen , funky drummer etc ) . When a snare backbeat transitions from the use of a snare to instead a rimshot......or a particular clap sample.....and that track blows up, the wave moves . If you a year later release a track with the old snare on the backbeat instead of the rim .....that’s dated . The same goes for the other percussions, the bass sounds (eg 808 / Moog in intro/bridge combi ) .....and the patterns . So this is why In twelve months most of the productions these artists are dithering over , will be out of date. It’s just silly imo. Music is moving so fast and is ultimately so disposable at the mo holding onto it like some sort of special Tolkien esque ring is really just a vanity. Personally I’d venture this is also the essence of what makes pop music trends discernible . That’s just my opinion tho with respect to these genres. My overall goal is to record and mix work like rumours. Smokey , earthy and nourishing . A bit like @popaganda.  s last work .🙏🏼

author: spectrummasters

After uni I’d do stage management/engineer assisting  at local venues in bristol volunterrring just to get experience......i did the wailers, ozomatli, pharcyde.....tons of two tone ska....while volunteering in dj workshops for local kids.....and up to today i always do some free stuff for rappers and singers in my area...because (and this is where i think mainstream often misunderstand rap lyrics).....it helps youngers express themselves and get shit off their chest....and off the streets.....and focuses their minds on ambition and change. In this way i think music is about grace....and as you said @BatMeckley  ...magic. What it brings into peoples lives and how it affects lives. The money i can take it or leave it....but the music i have to have. The most enriching musical experiences i can look back on have nothing to do with how much money was transacted

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Yo speaking on what @Nomograph Mastering said a few days about staying cool…we have a producer in and so the whole room is a giant mess (like most studios are when they are locked out) and we sold an amp and we wanted to make profiles/name of it before it went out the door 

So the patchbay is a huge mess and I hooked up all the routing and wasn’t getting signal and I started to lose my cool and got super frustrated, Rick calmed me down and we worked out what problem was (I forgot I was feeding the the amp from the di multed on the patchbay instead of feeding it from the converter to run tones..) and after I got cooled down it clicked on why I wasnmt getting signal.



It’s extremely difficult to not get frustrated when trouble shooting and not get overwhelmed by a full patchbay but if you just take a second and breathe/calm down and start reversing your signal flow you’ll find the culprit and move on




Long story short as an engineer you gotta be the calmest one in the room

author: frankieharper
content:
Thought for the end of the day… UK time 

Our arrangements and our mixes leap into existence from the womb of the metaphysical into a world rich in strict guidelines and predetermined boundaries. It’s drill, it NEEDS that thump… it’s lofi, it neeeeeds that blur, I want to get onto New Music Friday, it needs to be LoUd. 

Genre and playlists seem to rule with an iron fist… I often think that when an artist asks for a ‘brighter’ mix or an even MORE colossal 808. Not always… but often. 

Surely the overall and final sonic characteristic of our various musical expressions should be treated with as much emotional sensibility as our lyric or our narrative? 

Perhaps a dark lyric cries out for a dark mix… New Music Friday or otherwise?

Or is that built in?
 *wild generalisation hat firmly secured* 
Would it be too much of a reach to say that modern pop music is bright and loud because in recent history, pop music is high energy and bright in tone? Or is jazz historically observed from the back of a smoky leather bound room and so dark and dynamic just sits comfortably (whisky in hand) … I guess my question is… at risk of sounding a little Orwellian, do we control genre or does genre control us? Probably both? Asking for a friend.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Yeah for sure! Sounds like you're on a good path!! Totally understand the hesitation to delegate - especially that first 6 months-a year where you're acutely aware that helping someone else do it is *more work* than just rolling up your sleeves and doing it yourself. 

For building systems, what's worked for me is hiring and training your 'double(s)' first - someone with a similar skillset and sensibilities, very broad skills like me (who also did everything myself for a long time). This comes a lot easier if you have close friends in the same lane looking for jobs, I've seen people have their "double(s)" move in with them for a limited time too, with the intention of them soaking in exactly all you do.

Once my double(s) started doing pretty well, we started hiring more specialized people, and the doubles could then oversee their work, feedback etc - early on I would always be part of this, then slowly phase myself out.

What I wish I would have done earlier would have been to hire a producer/overseer/manager/'my boss' - someone with a bit more skin in the game/responsibility, and who keeps you in line if you start wavering. 

Again, I didn't love the setup of 10 and dissolved it eventually - as a creative it's easy to feel like you built a house/efficiency machine and one day you wake up and it's a prison that's not as flexible as you want. That's another thing I'm trying to keep in mind (I'm putting together a new similar team for this fall) - how do you keep the team agile and ready to shift when priorities shift? It could be as easy as accepting a little bit more churn & letting people go when they don't fit what's going on, but it's hard to let go of people you've trained and know well. I felt a friendship connection with my entire team, in hindsight I think that was a mistake too.

Those are some thoughts haha - what have you found so far? Are you experiences lining up with mine? What kind of roles are you hiring for?

author: Bonati12461
content: There are plenty of bad records out there - bad pressing quality and bad cuts (audio quality). Sometimes they don’t sound _bad_ but instead just really _boring_ - not so much “warm”, but dull. I think there are a lot of risk-averse, timid cuts being done by some cutting engineers out there - I feel like I can spot a “flat cut” from a mile away. Very hard to cut a digital master with no changes/processing and make it sound good (there are some exceptions). Cutting engineers need to work at it -  do a test cut, listen to it, make some changes, do another test cut. It can be laborious and that’s not always an awesome workflow but that is how to get to a much better sounding record.

author: ALXCPH
content:
For the kind of chops that your description seems to hint at, i would say it is all about tieing technique to your ears. (Assuming, you can already hum a melody on the spot and are not tone deaf) 

I wouldnt worry too much about theory and super correct technique. 

The best Way to get anywhere on an instrument is by Playing it, and doing in consistently. Set some realistic goals and just get going, vocabulary and technique Will come naturally if you just keep Playing. 

Fuck Playing scales and inversions and all that for now. 
Just go learn a metric ton of songs and melodies and learn to play them together. Do it by Ear. It Will be tough in the beginning, but you Will get very decent quickly if you just do the most important Thing, which is being consistent.

I would reccomend setting a low minimum to do everyday to keep a realistic goal that you can keep, rather than a higher on you miss every now and then. You can always add more practice but it sucks to miss out on it.

Start with song you want to Sound like and then you can slowly branch out when the style become second Nature for you. 

Sadly there are no tricks or hacks or whatever youtube wants you to beleive to get their clicks. Its all about muscle memory and developing your ears together. And not to Sound like 4 bar loop, but consistency, and do it a lot. I cannot stress that enough. ❤️

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. I've been going through a period these last few months where my enthusiasm to write and produce music has been flagging. I'm still listening to records every day - same as ever - but my approach has been to set the creation part aside completely and focus on the physical pleasures of playing.

For me that means focusing on singing for the first time in my life. Really taking the time to feel the physicality of it and how my body responds. Honing in on the sound and loosening up. I'm also playing more bass and focusing on the sensations and the tone and the articulation in a way that I've neglected for a while. Now I'm enjoying playing and singing together and practicing that with no expectations. I say this as someone who has never considered themselves to be a singer/songwriter. I'm really enjoying it.

The whole project is tied in with my mindfulness practice, and I'm loving the feeling of being unburdened by the need to write and deliver.

author: LAPhill
content:
Jumping in way late to this conversation, but some thoughts:

I'm broadly on board with @Rollmottle 's sentiments that no one is owed anything, especially in this line of work. That said, all music industry professionals, from mastering engineers to songwriters to musicians, increasingly are in a place where they need to prove why they're worth a premium cost. Premium is no longer newbie engineer vs. Serban, it's free plugins (or the artist's friend with a laptop full of cracked software) vs someone with reps at all. Maybe right now, the "premium" cost of engineering is minimum wage, but that is sadly still much more expensive than slapping CLA vocal and Ozone on your track with well-produced Splice loops. So why is your service worth more than that? It's an honest question that we all face.

I believe in the value of educating a client in why what we do costs what it does, but I'm not going to lose sleep over someone that can't see it. I see a ton of up-and-comers over valuing their worth and losing out on gigs because they don't understand how far they have to go. Engineers are often just as guilty at overvaluing themselves as artists are at undervaluing them. 

The one thing that does seem to still hold true in 2023 is that people that are doing consistently good work keep getting hired. And track records of reliability, decent (not even great!) work, and some credits that someone's heard of are all things to point to when talking about price. @Deleted User made a point of someone wanting him, but not seeing his value, and that's a particularly tough spot. Sometimes, you've just got to walk away from those people, as good as it feels to be in demand by someone.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
That's a great question. Does a balance need to be struck? I think it comes down to what we believe about our role in relation to the people we are working with. To someone who doesn't work much with other people to whom success is largely predicated on their lone creative genius maybe the question of balance is neither here nor there.

However, if you are on a team, are a leader, teacher, or coach suddenly you are on the hook with others and the performance of the group matters. The highest achievement, future funding, drawing in more talent, etc... might all come down to the performance of the group. Would it then be wise to be so laissez-faire about undermining the intrinsic motivation / confidence of others? What if an unintended consequence of that attitude is less actual human connection?

Last thought I had is how do we know the truth of someone else's potential? Fwiw I don't know the answers but this is what's kicking around my head.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well, it's hard to say what's best without a more holistic understanding of who you are and your circumstances, so I’m reluctant to offer any hard suggestions. Making a career in the music industry is what engineers would call a "wicked" problem. It's not something that has a repeatable solution, and what works for someone rarely works the same way for the next person.

That said, I see that you’re from Boston. I lived there for seven years, and the talent pool in that city is tremendous. I think if you found yourself back home in Boston it would be a worthwhile investment to integrate yourself into the scene of young musicians that are centered around the schools in the Back Bay like Berklee, NEC, and Boston Conservatory. There are some immensely talented, diverse, and creative people from all around the world based at those institutions and they all exist within 8 blocks of each other. It’s rare to have such a concentration of driven musicians all mingling amongst each other. This is a massive resource that you can tap into. They're *all* trying to make something great and explore what's possible.

It's a unique opportunity to discover collaborators, build relationships, earn experience in your craft, and build strong connections for the future as you grow alongside these people. On top of that, Boston has numerous recording studios where you can intern and assist. There’s a lot of experience to be gained working in a studio that simply won’t be taught to you in a recording program. Supplement that practical experience with hard work, and some book learning and you can do very well for yourself.

There’s more that I’m not touching-on, but I think if you ended up back in Boston it not be as much as a trade-off as you may think.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@rae this is a great discussion! Totally agree about open communication. It's something Jon and I talk about a lot. Learning how to have difficult discussions (even just learning 10 different ways to communicate "that still isn't good, let's do another take") is such a huge part of what we do. But honest, open communication is almost always the best solution. 

The only other thing I'll add regarding @Zack Hames's initial question is that I find it super valuable to continue to do all kinds of different roles. If I've mostly been programming and finishing productions, I'll take some time to write a song and sing it myself, so I stay "in shape" with writing and recording vocals. If I don't do something myself, how can I empathize with someone? My communication style is always one of "I know how you're feeling and you can trust me because I've done it a ton."

author: peterlabberton
content:
In my experience, if I’m mixing and not also producing, there’s almost always (maybe just always always?) someone who can act as a tie breaker. The producer, lead singer/songwriter, guitar dude who is clearly leading the charge creatively, a manager, etc. etc. who you can turn to in order to give definitive direction... maybe during covid this is more difficult as I feel that often can become clear organically in the room.

If it’s truly a situation where there are contradictory/unproductive notes coming in, maybe either a) tell them they need to decide amongst themselves and then give you a clear list of notes, or b) take the lead yourself and really push for what you feel serves the song best/explain why the sax can’t be 10x louder than the lead vocal? Which option is best I’d say depends on your relationship with them, how much of a lead you want to take creatively, how confident you are in making the right choices for this song, etc. etc.

At least that’s what I’d do. 🤷🏻‍♂️ @cian riordan might have better advise for these situations!

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’re going to get a lot of different responses, because there’s a lot of different answers! I think you already know what needs to happen; I’d think more about how.

Try one song a day for a week. Focus 1000% on the songwriting and almost nothing on the Sonics. Even if you don’t write a full song every day that week, I bet you’ll have spent more time than you would have without that goal. 

I’ve written and recorded some songs in a day. Some have taken literally 10 years. I’d try as many writing exercises that motivate and inspire you. Songwriting is 100% a muscle you can exercise.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Yes. The same way you do anything in life you want to get good at. Spend a shit load of time doing that thing. There really are no hacks or work arounds if you want to actually get good. An easy free way to do it is just learn as many songs as you can. If you want to really be proficient in the musical language I would recommend learning stuff by ear. It takes a lot longer than looking up tutorials or sheet music. But I promise you will develop your ears infinitely more. Specially in the beginning. Music is a language. Every human being learns to speak and converse before they learn how to spell and know the rules of grammar. Learning theory will only let you put names to sounds so that you can convey musical ideas to their people. Contrary to what a lot of people think, there are no rules, but there are a lot of conventions and traditions, but they keep changing and have lots of exceptions. Learning a shit ton of songs on whatever instrument you choose, will teach you what those conventions are and how to use them. 

In the beginning it’s good to just learn every song you like as well as you can, because it will help keep you motivated as you like the music. Then after a while you will probably want to branch out and try stuff you’ve never listened to or enjoyed before just to challenge yourself. 

The most musical people I know, are the people who wouldn’t know what to do with a Caugmented#9 but can listen to a song once and play it nearly perfectly, because their ears and musical language is so developed from playing a fuck lot of music and not spending time reading about it or watching endless tutorials.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve been using a nice workflow for AirPod checks recently.

1. Have an output from your monitor/output bus (I have it on a send in my template) to PT Bridge

2. Open QuickTime and open a new audio recording (Cmd + shift + N). 

3. Select PT Bridge as the QuickTime audio input. Turn up the volume slider to monitor

4. Select AirPods as system output 


Hey presto. Works great, no need to stream to phone etc. Just have to remember to turn down that QuickTime volume slider when you flip back to speakers. Also I occasionally accidentally start QT audio recording with spacebar when meaning to hit play in Tools. No biggie 🤷🏻‍♂️

This is an aside, but I had an extended conversation with Beckley about the mixed results of the TikTok trend.  My theory is that the biggest negative impact was caused by label execs trying to monetize the platform and doing a poor job of it. Making “viral” really the only barrier for entry, and trying to view things made off that platform as only viable if it would work ON it. 

In truth I think some real artists have come from TikTok, and some of the trends, like the drop (not new I know,) and the 30 second edit, are great tools for songwriting.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I love the short burst aspect of this a lot, I never would have thought of that. For lyrics, I have mostly done “journal entry” per day to amass tons of material to pick through later. I realized years later that almost all my completed songs with lyrics came from those bits of writing so I think I need to go back to that! (I don’t write lyrics a lot anymore).

For the music aspect, I relied heavily on just pure instinct / jam it out for so many years, but working on commercial music made me start to set a lot more intention in my writing which helped immensely in all aspects. I guess my favorite thing is mostly to try to write a fully structured song in a day (4-5 times a week). The limitation of a day gives me enough flexibility to actually create and record an entire track while also not getting TOO hung up on writing a verse, chorus, bridge, etc. there’s no time to overthink!

author: jantrit
content: I worked in kitchens for a long time, it allowed me to make some cash and live but also have flexibility to take music and studio jobs when they would come around. After moving to the states I found more restaurant work but kept it to only fri/sat/sun and tried to focus the rest of the week to build contacts and do studio stuff. I got super lucky with my boss who was also in the music thing and very understanding about calling out. It eventually got to the stage where I had to call out like 3 weekends in a row so I made the jump to doing the studio stuff full time. So far it’s been working out and I’ve been lucky to keep a good basis of projects, supplementing quiet periods with studio build stuff. It can be super stressful relying 100 percent on the music thing and it’s ultimately different strokes for diff folks. I’ve seen some people who get really burnt out taking music stuff that they don’t like to pay the bills and conversely I’ve seen people getting burnt out doing other stuff that’s not music getting effected in the same way. Ultimately whatever keeps ya happy and works for you is awesome, burn out is real.

author: ALXCPH
content: On a more specific note, in your case. Since you want to get better at composing melodies, learn a bunch of melodies and the underlying harmony and once you have learned a bunch, you will be able to just pick and chose from that knowledge and come up with your own melodies. A good thing to remember is, there are only 12 notes, and we rarely ever use more than 3-5 notes  in a melody in western music. It’s all based on rhythm and harmony to give those notes context.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
This was lovely to read. I’ve definitely been there on prod projects, and others. I’ll always allow projects to swell to fit the allowed time, which invariably adversely affects the quality of the work.

My vice is a deep seated tendency towards fucking around given the chance, and the energy and time that goes into that fuckery or exploration of alt options (which are NEVER as good as the first thing that inspires me) will ALWAYS have been better spent realising the first idea fully in the initial moment of inspiration.

I know this intellectually, but here I am at 7am voice noting out the structure of a pitch due today - doing the mapping out I should’ve done 4 days ago rather than trying out different drums, micing, guitar tones, etc etc on a 16 bar loop.

If anyone has a solution to this, I’d love to know how you’ve beaten your bad habits into submission.

author: ehutton21
content:
Piggy backing on a lot of the great thoughts in here and recalling my own musical education, I would say dividing the curriculum into a “listening” component and a “creating” component would be critical. In hindsight, it was incredibly formative for me that ear training practice and actual theoretical/sheet music knowledge always came alongside the practical element of sitting at keys and performing the pieces I was assigned that week.

I like the idea of breaking down modern pop structure, I like the idea of covering signal flow a lot. I think you can teach and test signal flow in theory while allowing someone to practice their recording technique by mimicking the song structure of their favorite pop song. I’m not proposing that as an actual coursework suggestion (I doubt most would be ready for that week one) but just as a thought for course organization

author: LAPhill
content:
In other quasi-AI developments, there's some pretty insane tech going on in the latest Unreal Engine demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dj60HHy-Kqk

About halfway through, they show some tools for moving elements around and the engine intelligently fills in the gaps and hooks it back into the environment seamlessly. Imagine this tech in a DAW - move a chord change, or a section, and all of the bits that would need to be adjusted to make it feel natural just happen automatically. You'd still have the flexibility to go in and adjust as desired, but as a way to instantly try ideas (or, respond to notes), there is a lot of potential there.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
In most instances, I feel I am fairly remunerated for my work at this stage. On the way to this point though, I did the grind and experienced the impact of that lifestyle on my mental and physical health, and on my personal life and relationships.

I'd rather people coming up now wouldn't have to endure the shitness that can abound, and to that end I sourced thoughts from a bunch of engineers, assistants, producers, mixers, and studios in the UK at the end of last year.

The list below was assembled from those conversations, and details some basic working conditions for music technicians working on a day rate basis (runners, assistants, tape/PT ops, engineers - not mixers, MEs, producers, or songwriters) that would bring us more in line with what have long been established and taken for granted by clients and employers in the comparable industries of theatre and film.

I'm not talking about bringing the industry to its knees here - just about establishing basic working conditions to safeguard the mental and physical health of our friends and colleagues.

I recognise that there are conditions specific to our industry and the nature of our work that would make some of these points less than straightforward to establish, so I'd love to hear everyone's thoughts on the below - whether they're reasonable, actionable, etc.

Pick some holes.

author: peterlabberton
content: And also, just listen! Like, get rid of anything visually distracting and listen through the song. Try to be just a listener and not a mixer—find the spots where something is either clashing or not speaking enough. Clashing: turn down the less interesting or important thing. Not speaking enough: turn up the compelling thing. Also pay attention to transition moments. Get the chorus to hit by turning the synth pad down leading into it, etc.

author: BatMeckley
content:
By all accounts she’s one of the best vocal producers/engineers around, so I’ve never had the chance to work with her. Can’t speak for her techniques. 

Revoice something I almost never use. In standalone melodyne on a lot of pop tracks if it’s a centered double I’ll make it spot dead on, almost to the point where it’s phasing, to beef up a lead to cut through a mix. If it’s singer songwriter Elliot smith vibe I’ll hard tune the double and for a tonal center and then let the lead breathe more to keep the character. Left Right doubles  you can’t tune as hard because they’ll start to collapse to mono which defeats the whole purpose.  

So again, it’s usually about working backwards from what you want, what it’s supposed to be, than it is about any one technique

author: Adam Thein
content:
This has been my anecdotal experience as well.  Especially when Melodyne 5 came out with sibilance detection I noticed a lot of phase smearing between blobs when you tuned a note before or after sibilance in the plugin version.  Standalone seems to handle that better.  I reported the issue the first day Melodyne 5 came out and the tech support basically shrugged for me and sent me on my way.

Especially in Ableton live where playback can sometimes start a sample or two off, I adopted the @BatMeckley Melodyne Workflow™️  and have been happy with it.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Seriously though....  this was inspired by a pop track string/winds  arrangement.  You'd think "well of course all the sample libraries I bought can do that just as well"  but not imxp....  its that the sample libraries can do "an adequate" job and satisfythe need.  But once you hire world-class players and play it live into mics....  for me it was instantly "we could've bought every sample library and programmed for days but never gotten this quality" in the tiny details.  The bow sounds. The players breathing together. Their adaptation to dynamics. The aleatoric sections where advanced techniques were improvised. Samples can be amazing and do things humans can't...  but the inverse is also true.  There are many context where it's got to be live players, or else your track is just "adequate"

There’s an old saying- good composers borrow ideas, great composers steal them. 

A LOT of John Williams’ most iconic themes are copy & paste from inner voices in things like the Brahm’s Requiem or Tchaikovsky’s Swan Lake etc.  

My advice is take a line from a second verse in a song you love and make that your hook. Extrapolate.

author: Slow Hand
content:
What you describe feels like what I think of as "conceptual alignment". When the essence of the song is fully realized because all elements are working in harmony (or sometimes appropriately discordant).

On those records the underlying emotion and message are expressed when the chords, melody, lyrics, sonics, and performance are all working in service of that thing. Every element is pushing in the same direction. They feel aligned.

Like a classical painting in which you can *feel* a strong emotion immediately because the composition, expression of the figures, color choice, and flow of movement in the image are all "pointing" at the underlying essence.

Does that sound at all like what you're experiencing?

author: dylannash
content:
What are some of your favourite elements of your prod/mix templates? I currently have a separate production/writing template and then another for mixing but I’m trying to hybridise and streamline them a little more to get faster results and hopefully focus on the song. Also, most of the songs I mix tend to be one’s I’ve written and produced as well, so hoping to cut down on session set-up time.

Some of mine are an instant “duck bus”, which I picked up from Ian Kirkpatrick. It’s a pre-loaded aux with something like LFO Tool or shaper box on it, so you can quickly route and uniformly make things side chain.

Another quick workflow thing I love is having Pro Tools audio playlists with a bunch of reverse sweeps, impacts and other transition fx/ear candy hidden and ready to go in the session, so you can quickly try out a bunch. 

I also have the trim plugin added as the first and last plugin on every new track preset, as I use them to quickly manage the gain in and out of each track and so I don’t have to search for them constantly.

Ozone Spectral shaper on some music busses and as a replacement for Soothe on the mix bus has also been a real win (thanks Jon!) Although these sorta things aren’t turned on whilst writing as they have a ton of latency.

Keen to hear what you all find useful!

author: skinnybreakfast
content:
Sorry for the book incoming. But this is plaguing my mind. Has there been an in-depth discussion on live or in discord yet about musicians on tiktok? 

It's a crazy scene of selling your creative soul for 1 minute of attempting to go viral. and then if you do get a popular video, whatever that one was - that is now your thing... singing into a trash can doing RHCP covers... ok, now do another 100 of those.  I see so much talent on there, genuine talent and artists who have worked hard on their craft getting 10 views due to the algo... once the algo has tried your vid on a few people and it didn't stick the vid is dead... so it's totally hit and miss based on your first small sample of viewers.

I see this having a huge impact in many ways. On the plus - you are getting exposure to incredible new ideas, skills, trends, methods for being creative... on the negative it's demotivating to the nth degree, and cheapening the creative process, in my opinion.

Matt and Jon recently talked about track lengths getting shorter and shorter, now 2 minutes is the normal. Partly due to the attention span of people... well what is this going to do... 1 minute pop tracks incoming? Just gimme the hook in 30 seconds and let's move on please. :p. How can we get young people to lay on the floor and listen to 10 minute vinyl tracks again? In my opinion humanity NEEDS this :)) 

I also swear I've heard the influence of trending memes from tiktok coming through in music in the charts, but cannot really back this up.

What's everyone else's thoughts? I have a friend in LA who says everyone has gone crazy there for tiktok fame? 😛

author: Slow Hand
content: I think you're also right that the music of memes and Tik-Tok edits are starting to creep into popular music. I think that's exciting. It's layered and fun. As long as the core material is compelling it's all fine to me. My one reservation might be if you need to have full cultural context to appreciate the "meme-ness" of the song. If the record doesn't hold up on it's own outside of that cultural context then it's probably weak songwriting. It's window of relevance is limited.

author: Slow Hand
content: The Fiery Furnaces did a really neat live album a decade ago where they spliced together all of their live performances into a full album. Now many bands do that already, but they combined multiple takes for each *song.*  They'd take the chorus from Night 1 and splice it onto the second verse of night 4 and then do the outro from Night 7. The cool part was that the recordings, rooms, and audience are drastically different, so you end up with lots of cool sonic shifts on the downbeats of each section in the songs.

author: peterlabberton
content: Lotta good answers so far so I’ll just say +1 to the above. I’ll *also* add that the ceiling for what you can earn here in music is *way* higher. I moved from San Francisco 5 years ago. I had a good thing going there and was well connected to a bunch of other full-time working music folks—you can charge way more in LA for your services than you can just about anywhere else. author: Ross Fortune
content:
**Keyboard players (and songwriters) of LWMR:** I need to seriously up my keyboard chops this year. 

I’ve been keyboard catting my way through life up to now - mashing out left hand root notes and RH triad shapes to get the rhythm and feel down, then fixing the notes / adding removing midi.  Fine by myself, but infuriating for anyone else in the room. 
 
I’m going to be in some (mostly writing) situations where that’s not going to cut it - I need to be much more fluent.

What are some efficient ways to get there? I’ve tried putting myself through the school of YouTube, but I haven’t found a course prescriptive enough to keep me focused and on track - just loads of disparate technique tutorials, and I don’t know what order to take them in. Also took some lessons, but cost and scheduling were unsustainable.

If it helps, my theory and reading were at one point strong and can probably be dredged back up if needed.

author: ehutton21
content:
To @Rollmottle’s point, maybe I can bridge this gap here, but from the perspective of someone dealing with mental health issues, it’s a fine line between empowerment and complete lack of accountability. There are ways of accommodating people that empower them, and that’s important. Part of that accommodation looks like recognizing that when someone has a really bad go, they’re going to struggle to assimilate themselves into the rest of society some days. But on the flip side, people with mental health issues are people. My bipolar ass can drive a car—doesn’t mean I get to drive off the road and cause collisions whenever I’d like, and even at my worst I’m capable of knowing that. 

Anxiety is difficult in that you often border on delusions—panic attacks are delusions about experiencing serious medical issues for a huge swath of people, and while that can make it difficult to do things like eat on a regular basis, I have to be mindful that having a stringent routine that keeps my triggers at bay is critical.

author: cian riordan
content: Insight gives you A LOT of visual information that isn't really useful unless you know what you're looking for. I have two visual meters while I mix... a janky old Goldline RTA analyzer and a TC Electronics Clarity. The RTA is useful for quick visual cues of kick to snare balance, how subby something really is, or when I'm working out phase relationships between drum mics... I can quickly glance to help aid with decision making. It's not necessary for me to mix, but I've had it for 15 years and it helps me make certain technical decisions quicker. The Clarity is very useful for the loudness radar. I basically set a guide LUFS (in my case, I'm usually shooting for -9) and you get a great visual representation of where you're at over the course of the song. Its especially useful to avoid fader creep... where I might nail the dynamics and loudness in the earlier parts of the song, but might overlook the last chorus being significantly louder, and in some cases, more squashed than it needs to be. I'm also an LCR panning guy, and it has a 'balance-o-meter' feature that has a cool weighted algorithm for determining if your mix is leaning left or right.

author: Will Melones
content:
I get the impression that *your* taste is both incredibly diverse and highly refined, and while it may not align with the general public, it’s far from “bad taste”. I also don’t feel like someone who only likes to listen to the top of the charts has better taste, although you could say it’s empirically true that they do.

The fact that you’ve deliberately chosen to create something that’s not for everyone brings me back to the Conversations episode about the Service-Artisan Continuum. There’s no need to plant your flag on the service end of the spectrum if it doesn’t bring you joy and there’s food on your table. And there’s nothing that says you can’t serve clients by day and let creativity run wild by night.

If you’ve got something profound to say, it would be a damn shame to water it down for the public’s taste. I don’t think Radiohead would have had the impact that they did if they’d written another “Creep”.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think his point isn’t that passion entitles living, but passion becomes a way of manipulation that justifies no pay. 

But to your point regarding leverage, I can’t deny that leverage is important and being good is the best leverage. 

But I think that’s beyond what we’re talking about. Especially in  songwriting land, there are plenty of people who wrote hits that weren’t compensated accordingly. 

Restaurant business sucks, but if you’re good- you can make profits. Each neighborhoods have profit making restaurants. But when it comes to music industry, the proportion of those who actually make money is way low compared to restaurant business. In restaurant business, you still pay the workers regardless. You have to. In music, if the artist isn’t making money then the ones who get hired by artists have no chance of making money

author: LAPhill
content:
I'm trying to zoom out here. Like, what is the actual revenue being brought in by the artists you're hoping to work with? Where is money to be made and who's making it? 

Picking a nice round number, if you're an engineer on an album that gets a million streams a year, that's something like $4000 for the artist. Hopefully they generate money from touring, but based on the album's services alone, how much could an artist reasonably pay if their ROI is $4k?

If the gamble is to get hooked up with a new artist who has the potential to break through, the producer's points on a hit is where real money could be made, right? So pricing yourself to get at many chances at the lottery would likely be more fruitful than a few extra hundred per gig, but it's a gamble. Between repeat clients and chance for a moderate hit, it seems like a better way to spend your time

All that said, as you pointed out, this ain't my lane.

Could be lyrical, emotional, or intentional aspect of the song in the context of music, but it generally has to do with what this piece of art was inspired by and what it is talking about on the inside. author: LAPhill
content:
I've walked away from exactly 1 project in my career. Because life is too short and it was a bridge I had no qualms about burning. 

In general yes, powering through can be a better preservationist strategy for your career, but you only have so much to give. On difficult projects, sometimes the thing that keeps me going is a second project. Even though that's even more work, having something enjoyable to jump to when I'm running on empty can give me enough fuel to keep going. Relegate it to the sidelines and mitigate its impact on your psyche. This does not at all mean do anything less than your 100%, but try to adjust your schedule in a way that allows joy and fun to come through in other places.

author: Joshua Riley
content:
Been doing some searching of the Discord this afternoon but struggling to find much. 

I’d love to hear some wisdom on the generalist vs specialist topic

I’m personally just a mixer. Mostly pop music. A lot of my work is with producers or self produced artists and overseeing the final engineering of a project (mixing the track and then passing off to an ME)
I’m also one of the young ones so a lot of my connections that I make and work are through social media whether it be artists or producers. I don’t want to open a can of worms but I’m just finding so many people that are wearing the generalist hat (specifically from a producer standpoint). Seeing a lot of credits that involve one person Co-writing, producing, mixing and mastering a record or seeing a lot of productions where the mixer is completely bypassed because the prod & mix is done by the same person. Would just love to hear peoples opinions on the topic

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I start with Slow Burn from Kacey and about halfway through the first verse I ask them where the vocal is coming from, to teach them about phantom center. 

Then it’s Owl City and after the intro I ask ‘em where they notice all those plinky plonkies to talk about sides and imaging. 

Then it’s maybe Khalid’s Better to hit that JC Bottom. 

Then depending on who they like, I’ll play them something in their particular genre that I know to be an interesting listen in the studio. 

Then I set ‘em free to listen to whatever they want.

author: Deleted User
content:
there are traditional jazz and modern jazz. people who do traditional like to honor the head (the melody of jazz standard). A close friend of mine is a modern Jazz Saxophonist, he said he once broke up with his band after an argument because he didn’t want to play the melody but his band members were more traditional and wanted him to play the head. 

Imo calling something not Jazz because they aren’t doing the head-solo-head form is like calling modern classical music not classical music because of the aleatoric composition. Somewhat of a valid opinion, but not really. 

Would you call wayne shorter not a jazz musician because he writes scores for his band? (well… he’s also a free jazz musician…) 

For general public, traditional jazz and traditional classical music would be more appealing to listen to for most people due to the predictability factor. Modern classical music and modern jazz is a movement to explore creative possibilities beyond that, but… it’s often not done so tastefully because they step too far off the predictability.

But Jazz is a free form of expression. I think a lot of non-jazz musicians hate on Jazz because it’s somewhat cerebral (it really isn’t once you get past it… which I couldn’t just yet), and a lot of people choose music because of its unexplainable magic people experience from it. It’s only natural that the same people that was attracted to the unexplainable nature of music being turned off by the explainable nature of harmonies and rhythms. Jazz noobs and Berklee kids may make it look like that what Jazz is about and some have elitism behind it too, but that’s not jazz. All the theory and stuff is a door you go through to be able to step into the world of self expression with an open form. (to be fair many old school jazz musicians solely played by ear with no knowledge in music theory. because… it all comes from their ears at the end of the day)

Whether one wants to sit through someone expressing themselves is theirs to decide.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
**Sound, Feel and Peak Wow**

I suspect many Engineers have a similar trajectory when it comes to audio

- First your musical lights come on, often via your parents taste, an older brother or maybe school friends
- Sometime soon after you realize that music makes you feel like nothing else, it speaks to your interiority in a way that other arts do not
- OK … now you’re hooked and you start to wonder *why* sounds make you feel the way they do? You start paying close attention to the textures, the colors and the detail of audio
- Next you start working with audio and start learning how to manipulate sound. Soon you are chasing the work of your idols! Killer drums tones, deep verbs, tripped out delay throws, beautiful vocal textures … all the stuff we love
- Your journey continues and hopefully over time you have access to better songs, players, gear, rooms etc and the quality of your sonic output continues to improve

You may eventually arrive at “Peak Wow”

This is the moment where your ability and gear allows you to actually create and wield the sounds that set you on this crazy journey. Your mixes are wide, and deep and loud and impressive and hit and knock and do all of the things …. “WOW, that sounds amazing” ….

But notice we haven’t mentioned feel in a minute. Here’s what I think happens to a lot of Engineers, some graduate out of it and some don’t

Liken our journey described above to using your hands to make shadow animals on a wall. You probably don’t remember the first time you saw that as a kid but it’s wild! Pretty soon you’ve got a pair of bunny ears going, and maybe a swan or a spider

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Ah that makes sense for you!! I see a lot of people successfully doing media planning (release scheduling etc) with ChatGPT now - that seems to be one of the areas where AI can do a pretty stellar job, but you'd still need someone to look over/execute.

Overall it sounds like you might need someone with a pretty broad skillset. I'd look at an ex youtuber/part time youtuber in your position probably, but few of them have the technical chops to make lyric videos or film acoustic videos to a high standard - I'd suggest those are two different roles, unless you get very lucky. The cinematography and lyric video making (motion graphics) are also considered more high paying skillsets, so even if you do find someone with the entire range of skills, you might end up paying more than splitting them up.

Overall your plan sounds good! Sounds great that you're willing to be hands off, that will pay immensely in my experience. 

Re: meetings, I don't really have an approach apart from avoiding them as much as possible. Try to schedule group calls when it's possible to multitask. What kind of meetings do you have with your team now?

author: markmaclure
content:
Hey everyone. I’ve been doing a lot of thinking about “point of view” when it comes to artists, and I’d love to hear the community’s thoughts. 

Most successful artists (by numbers, following, cultural impact, etc) tend to have a certain point of view. It’s often somewhat broad and difficult to pinpoint  exactly what it is. Charli XCX has a song about doing cocaine at a club and a song wondering if she will run out of time to have a baby on the same album, but neither feels out of place. The Sabrina record has multiple distinct sonic landscapes within it but they feel coherent when played next to each other. “Slim Pickins” and “Bed Chem” come to mind as pretty different from each other. Post Malone and Beyoncé both went country and it seemed perfectly natural. All of these projects feel like they have a distinct point of view despite an evolving multitude of lyrical content and sonics. 

When I hear less successful artists, I often perceive a lack of a point of view. Their perspective may feel generic, it might jump around in a way that isn’t coherent, or it might not be the best representation of who they are. Sometimes the music might be coming from a genuine place and is GREAT, but it doesn’t quite land because the artist hasn’t been able to pinpoint exactly who they are sonically/lyrically/artistically and also how exactly to bring that into the world. Sometimes their preconceptions of who they are or preoccupation with a shiny new idea can get in the way too.

author: markmaclure
content:
I think Rick Rubin producing “Under The Bridge” was a masterclass in what I’m trying to understand. Maybe? I think he understood the point of view of RHCP better than they themselves did. He found a little piece of magic and somehow got the band to let go of their prior conceptions of their identify and record the song. Some Jedi shit for real. 

How do I do that? Should I do that? How should we as producers think about point of view when creating for/with artists? To what extent should we be involved in crafting the point of view? What should we do when an artist has potential but is lacking a distinct point of view? What is even is point of view?

Any thoughts would be welcome.

author: markmaclure
content: I wonder how Rick felt when he found those lyrics in Kiedis’ notebook. It seems like he had to stand up for the song a bit, was that “following the art” or did he preconceive that this is a RCHP song?

author: markmaclure
content: And that raises more questions. Which art should I follow when the artist and I have different instincts? If Rick followed Kiedis’ version of the art we wouldn’t have under the bridge
